node.title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘A Child I’ll Never Meet’
node.description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
node.content: ["Walking home, I stopped before a poet for hire and told him I\u2019d had eggs retrieved from my ovaries to create a child I\u2019ll never meet. I expected him to be shocked, but he\u2019d just learned that his mother has other children, so he understood, in a way. He sees strangers with her dimples on the train and wonders. To the child I imagine: I have tried to do something useful, but I\u2019ve also tried to create strangers whose faces I might recognize on the train. I kept the poem in case one of them is ever you. \u2014 Kathryn Phelan", "Minh says I\u2019m hard to buy gifts for. Yet every day I anticipate him coming home with little offerings: cookies wrapped in napkins sneaked out of faculty workshops, a bottle of sanitizer, a ChapStick from a job fair. When Minh gives larger gifts, he often confuses the holidays. Among Christmas presents? A \u201cMost Wonderful Mom\u201d button. For my birthday? Books and a pumpkin-shaped eraser. Next year is our 25th anniversary. I will pretend to sneer as I unwrap each gift. Then laugh. It\u2019s not easy to please a woman already content, a woman who has the best life can give. \u2014 Nhi Huynh", "A two-flat house, my grandparents\u2019 little \u201cslice of paradise\u201d in bustling Chicago, raised generations of our family. But when my grandma turned 94, it became too much for her to live there alone. I was distraught when she died three weeks after we moved her out of her beloved home. Near the six-year anniversary of her passing, my mother and I drove by the house to see it. Surprisingly, there was a \u201cfor rent\u201d sign in the lawn. Now I wake up there every morning, look at my grandmother\u2019s photo on the wall and tell her, \u201cWe made it home.\u201d \u2014 Kathryn Jaslikowski", "Jim was a striking combination of three friends I had crushes on, all of whom were straight. Luckily, Jim was gay and we shared a mutual friend who introduced us 42 years ago. It took Jim a while to realize that I meant to love him. I persevered until he reciprocated my feelings. We partnered and married. When Jim became ill, I took care of him for six years as his eyes shone but his body became a shadow. Now I\u2019m on my own again, looking not for a duplicate of Jim but a complement. It\u2019s tough at 77! Persevere. \u2014 Gil Narro Garcia"]
